awd_titl_txt: Scholarships Combined with Targeted Support Services to Increase Student Success in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program will support the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at the Miami Dade College Homestead Campus (MDC-HC). This project aims to award a total of more than 300 semester-long scholarships to at least 60 academically talented STEM students with financial need. The project has three phases. In the first phase, participants will complete a paired mathematics and Student Life Skills course, through which they will gain improved study habits, time management, and other skills to enhance their academic experience and improve their performance in the math course. The following term, participants enter the One Step Up phase, in which they will apply the skills acquired during the first phase and demonstrate a strong motivation to succeed in their chosen STEM pathway. Faculty mentors, advisors, and instructors will address needs to support student momentum and progression in this phase.  The third phase, Stepping Out, will occur during the final two college terms and will include field trips to universities and STEM employers, presentations by STEM professionals, research experiences, and aid with transfer to four-year institutions.

The project will conduct a research study to address the following questions: (1) Does the pairing of a credit-bearing mathematics course with a student life skills course increase the success in a mathematics course?  (2) How can the institution design interventions that will help low-income students sustain sufficient motivation to succeed in STEM pathways? (3) What factors contribute most to the success of a talented student from a low-income family in a STEM career pathway, including factors in the social environment (e.g., personal factors at home, family support) and the academic environment (e.g., adequate advisement, tutoring)? and (4) How do psychosocial constructs (such as math/science self-efficacy, science identity, and leadership/teamwork self-efficacy) of low-income, academically talented STEM students change over time when they are provided STEM-specific academic supports and career related interventions?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Step2Stem project aimed to support low-income, minority students in pursuing STEM careers. The project focused on designing interventions to maintain student motivation and identify factors that contribute to their success. Here is a summary of the key outcomes and findings, addressing both intellectual merit and broader impacts.

The Step 2 Stem project has significantly contributed to understanding how to support low-income, minority students in STEM pathways. The project implemented a combination of academic and extracurricular activities to help students succeed. Key interventions included:

  1. Course Enrollment and Support: Students were enrolled in specific classes designed to build necessary skills, such as the SLS 1510 - Student Life Skills course and a combination of MAT 1033 (Intermediate Algebra) and MAC 1105 (College Algebra). 
  2. Extracurricular Activities: Students were encouraged to join clubs and undergraduate research programs to establish a sense of belonging and maintain motivation. The Genius Hour, a weekly presentation by professionals from various careers, provided students with advice and experiences.  Students also participated in workshops that helped them develop study habits, financial budgeting, time management, and goal planning.
  3. Cohort Performance: The project tracked the performance of four cohorts from 2019 to 2024. Despite challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, the project achieved a 70.7% retention rate and an average GPA of 3.38.

Findings from Graduating Students Survey results from graduating students indicated high satisfaction with the program. Students reported that the program helped them connect with peers, figure out career goals, and develop time management, writing, and critical thinking skills. The program's holistic approach, combining academic support with extracurricular activities, proved effective in helping students succeed.

The Step 2 Stem project also had a significant impact on the lives of participating students and the broader community. Key broader impacts include:

  1. Increasing Social Mobility: By supporting low-income, minority students in STEM pathways, the project has increased their chances of completing higher education degrees, leading to better career opportunities and higher salaries.
  2. Strengthening STEM Identities: The project helped students develop a strong STEM identity by exposing them to professionals in their field and providing opportunities for research and internships. This empowerment enabled students to see themselves as successful in STEM careers.
  3. Community Engagement: The program established itself as part of the local community by meeting with parents and creating the YES club for environmental sustainability at Homestead Campus.

Challenges and Adaptations The COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupted the program, affecting recruitment and support efforts. Despite these challenges, the project successfully recruited 58 students, just shy of the goal of 60, and graduated 53.4% of the students, although this was below the target of 80%. The pandemic highlighted the importance of in-person interactions for student success, as cohorts that experienced fewer disruptions performed better academically.

Impact on Teaching and Educational Experiences The project emphasized the need for teaching to be collaborative and move beyond the classroom to focus on the "whole" student. The team-taught approach, where the learning outcomes of the Student Life Skills course were aligned with a combined Mathematics course, helped students successfully complete math prerequisites. This model of integrating curricular and co-curricular activities can serve as a model for other community colleges to increase student success in STEM pathways.

In conclusion, the Step 2 Stem project made significant strides in supporting low-income, minority students in STEM pathways. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, the project achieved a 70.7% retention rate and helped students develop essential skills for their academic and professional futures. The project's holistic approach, combining academic support with extracurricular activities, proved effective in increasing student success and can serve as a model for other institutions seeking to support underrepresented students in STEM fields.


Last Modified: 03/18/2025
Modified by: Eduardo A Araujo-Pradere
